author: By Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
title: Saudi Arabia Pledges to Send Funding for Palestinians

content: Gail Collins: Well, Bret, the mayor of New York is certainly in a ton of trouble. Any thoughts? I couldn’t help noticing that a lot of Eric Adams’s misdeeds seem to involve him getting cushy flights to places like Turkey and Sri Lanka. Remembering the scandal over Justice Clarence Thomas’s super-luxe flights in a plane belonging to a billionaire named Harlan Crow.

content: Maria Magner was six months pregnant with her second child when a seizure led to the discovery of a brain tumor. Given that she was well into her third trimester, her medical team was hesitant to begin the aggressive treatment needed, but she eventually started chemotherapy, had a successful surgery and underwent radiation. She is now in remission and her daughter is healthy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kris Kristofferson: 12 Essential Songs
description: The country singer and songwriter, who died on Saturday at 88, tucked enduring aphorisms into tales about facing up to loss.
content: Kris Kristofferson, who was 88 when he died on Saturday, embedded enduring aphorisms into his songs. “Freedom’s just another word for nothing left to lose,” he observed in “Me and Bobby McGee.” In “Help Me Make It Through the Night,” he wrote, “Yesterday is dead and gone/And tomorrow’s out of sight.” And in “For the Good Times,” he urged, “There is no need to watch the bridges that we’re burning.”

title: How to Help Victims of Hurricane Helene

content: Hurricane Helene brought widespread damage across the South, leaving more than 100 people dead, thousands without power and many without access to food and water.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sony Pictures Names Ravi Ahuja C.E.O.

content: Sony Pictures Entertainment said on Monday that its chief executive, Tony Vinciquerra, will step down at the beginning of next year and be succeeded by the studio’s president and chief operating officer, Ravi Ahuja.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Good Reason for Rural Rage: The Crushing Power of Corporate Meat
description: Highlighting efforts to reduce the power of Big Ag over farmers can be a winning strategy for Harris.
content: It’s no secret that rural Americans are angry with the Washington elite. Less discussed are some of the sensible reasons for it. For far too long, family farms have been crushed under the monopolistic power of Big Ag. And for decades, politicians from both parties either turned a blind eye to the oligopolies that rule over rural America — or climbed right into bed with them.
source.name: The New York Times

content: A few songs into the first night of Hit Me Hard and Soft: The Tour at the Videotron Center in Quebec City, Billie Eilish challenged the sold-out crowd of 18,000 to play the quiet game. “It’s literally the only time in the entire show I’m going to say this,” assured the superstar, 22, who sat cross-legged on the floor at center stage, “because I don’t want silence, ever.”

title: The Mexican Novelist Who Found Himself in New Orleans

content: There’s an argument to be made that New Orleans is as much a part of Yuri Herrera as the cities in Mexico that raised him. He’s lived here for 13 years. It’s where he met his wife and adopted two dogs; where he gained a deeper understanding of the codes and contradictions of being Black, white and brown in America; where he lost a good friend to violence; and where he earned, if not quite enemies, something like them.

author: By Nicole Acheampong
title: The Secret Art of David Hammons
description: Through interviews with some of his colleagues and collaborators — and several rare images — T considers the last half-century of an elusive artist’s practice.
content: In the 1970s, the artist David Hammons started gathering hair from Black barbershops. In New York, he tacked the strands onto grease-slicked paper bags to make multidimensional collages, topped off with a few bones from barbecue ribs and a sprinkle of glitter. In Los Angeles, he affixed small tufts to pieces of wire and stuck them into the sands of Venice Beach; he let those wash away with the tides. He didn’t care much about making a work that he could sell. Then as now, Hammons wasn’t interested in catering to the art market — or even necessarily speaking to it. Over the course of his approximately 60-year-career, Hammons, 81 and currently based in the New York area, has participated in very few interviews. In a defining one from a 1986 issue of Real Life Magazine with the curator and historian Kellie Jones, he discusses his disdain for traditional galleries. “The rooms are almost always wrong, too much plasterboard, overlit, too shiny and too neat,” he says. “The work should be somewhere in between your house and where you’re going to see it.”

author: By Ross Barkan
title: ‘The Power Broker’ Is Magisterial. It Is Also Flawed.
description: We need to recapture faith in government to be a great builder again.
content: When I was 22 and working at a local newspaper in Queens, I opened up “The Power Broker” for the first time. I sat in a park in the borough’s leafy eastern reaches, within a short drive of a Robert Moses-constructed bridge (the Bronx-Whitestone) and a Robert Moses-constructed expressway (the Clearview). I commuted to work from my apartment in the southwest corner of Brooklyn, enduring the Moses parkways and expressways, driving myself to madness in one rush-hour traffic scrum after another. I came to believe this long-dead urban planner had locked me in an asphalt prison that I could never escape.

title: The Stakes on Abortion
description: We explain where Kamala Harris and Donald Trump stand on the issue.
content: The question of whether women should be allowed to end a pregnancy has roiled American politics for more than half a century. But this year’s presidential race is the first since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, and abortion politics and policy are changing rapidly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Kellen Browning and Nailah Morgan
title: We Watched Tim Walz’s Old Debates. Here’s What We Learned.
description: He may not be a lofty orator, but he has shown an ability to deliver punchy critiques with Everyman appeal.
content: Follow live updates on the vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: For Hours, He Clung to a Tree and Cried for Help. But None Came.
description: Bruce Tipton, 75, was in his trailer home when it was washed away by Tropical Storm Helene’s floodwaters. As his agonized family watched, he slipped into the raging river.
content: The hollering went on for hours, barely audible over the roar of the thrashing French Broad River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Oasis Adds North American Shows to Reunion Tour
description: Liam and Noel Gallagher’s band will stop in three American cities plus Toronto and Mexico City in August and September 2025.
content: In August, when Oasis revealed a slew of reunion dates in Britain and Ireland starting next summer, the group said that plans were still underway for shows in “other continents outside of Europe.” That led to rampant speculation on social media — including purportedly leaked itineraries — about where the Britpop stars might go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: Stocks in Japan Tumble After Party’s Election of New Prime Minister
description: Stocks dropped after Japan’s governing party chose Shigeru Ishiba, a critic of the country’s longstanding ultralow interest rates, as its leader.
content: Stocks in Japan fell sharply on Monday after the country’s governing party chose a leader some view as hawkish on interest rates, underlining how central bank decisions continue to set the course of the world’s fourth-largest economy after decades of easy money policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of Nasrallah’s Death
description: Plus, we retraced one of Mayor Eric Adams’s lavish trips to Istanbul.
content: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed on Friday near Beirut, Lebanon, in an attack that Israel’s military said had hit the militant group’s headquarters. Nasrallah was a beacon for anti-Israel forces across the Middle East and beyond, and his death is a major blow to Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump, No Stranger to Playing Storm Politics, Visits a Battered Georgia
description: In Valdosta, Ga., Donald Trump made a false claim about President Biden’s responsiveness and demonstrated his long-held instinct to view disaster response through the prism of his personal politics.
content: Minutes after touching down in storm-ravaged Valdosta, Ga., former President Donald J. Trump made an elaborate false claim about the Biden administration’s response to Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 478
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 1, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: In This Nuclear Family, Mental Illness Leads to a Meltdown
description: Betsy Lerner’s assured first novel, “Shred Sisters,” maps the effects of a daughter’s volatility on her parents and younger sister.
content: Whatever eldest daughter syndrome is, Ollie Shred doesn’t have it. According to the dubious science of birth order and the recent internet, big sisters are the disproportionate load bearers of the family: responsible, organized, high-achieving, resentfully overburdened. According to Amy Shred, her big sister is reckless, self-absorbed, volatile, manipulative. A danger to herself and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin, Ben Hubbard and Lazaro Gamio
title: What to Know About the Axis of Resistance, the Iran-backed Militia Network
description: The alliance is under scrutiny after the recent Israeli strikes in Lebanon.
content: The death of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, in an Israeli airstrike last week has focused attention on the armed groups supported by Iran that are dedicated to countering American and Israeli influence in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Marge Locker
title: The Magnificently Weird Fiction of Yoko Tawada
description: The Japanese author, frequently mentioned as a possible Nobel laureate, has a new novel, the second in her “Scattered All Over the Earth” trilogy.
content: “Suggested in the Stars” is the second in Yoko Tawada’s trilogy of friendship amid climate change dystopia, begun by “Scattered All Over the Earth,” published in English in 2022. The books combine the innocence of The Baby-Sitter’s Club with the Surrealism of Leonora Carrington’s art. They are, simply put, deeply weird. And while the word “weird” has recently had a moment as an insult on the political stage, Tawada’s work reminds us that weirdness is not always a bad thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fawaz A. Gerges
title: The Rising Risk of a New Forever War
description: The “total victory” that Netanyahu and his cabinet are seeking over Hezbollah will not bring the absolute security that Israelis want and need.
content: The immediate jubilation among Israelis over the airstrike that killed the longtime Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah on Friday is premature. Israel’s dramatic escalation in its conflict with Hezbollah, the Iran-backed militant group, poses a serious risk of embroiling both Israel and the United States in a costly forever war — an outcome that will bring neither stability nor peace to Israel or the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Is Denied New Trial After Dismissal of Alec Baldwin’s Case
description: The armorer’s lawyers failed to convince the judge that the same evidence dispute that led her to toss the actor’s manslaughter charge had deprived their client of a fair trial.
content: A judge in New Mexico declined on Monday to grant a new trial to the armorer in the fatal “Rust” shooting, who had accused the prosecution of suppressing evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Officials Believe Israel Will Not Conduct Full Invasion of Lebanon
description: After a weekend of intense talks, the American officials said they believed that Israel was planning only smaller, targeted incursions in southern Lebanon.
content: American officials said on Monday that they believed they had persuaded Israel not to conduct a major ground invasion of southern Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Verdict on Alessandro Michele’s Valentino
description: Major change is in the air, in all sorts of ways.
content: Goodbye Hôtel Salomon de Rothschild, the ornate 19th-century hôtel particulier in the 8th Arrondissement of Paris that for years had played rococo host to the Valentino fashion shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jed Handelsman Shugerman
title: The Case Kamala Harris Can’t Stop Prosecuting
description: Being tougher on so-called frauds, cheaters and financial predators would make the criminal justice system a bit more equal.
content: As Kamala Harris seeks to become the first career prosecutor to win the presidency, she has faced persistent questions: What kind of prosecutor was she? And how would that background shape her presidency? Instead of fitting into the familiar categories, she has been campaigning as another first: the first white-collar-crime prosecutor in chief. Instead of policies to reverse mass incarceration, the signature objective of progressive prosecutors, her approach seems to be for more equal incarceration, a new twist on an old populist economic theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles W. McFarlane
title: They’ve Made Hats for McCain and Trump. And Obama and Harris.
description: One of the last remaining union-run hat factories in the country is in New Jersey. Over more than three decades, its workers have made hats for competing campaigns.
content: On an afternoon in September, in a 70,000-square-foot factory in New Jersey, the brims of thousands of camouflage hats were being steamed into a gentle bend so they could be boxed up and shipped across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Michel Houellebecq’s Outlook for an Ailing France: C’est Fini
description: In what the author says is his last novel, both a family and a society are on the verge of collapse.
content: The French writer Michel Houellebecq has the sort of notoriety, Karl Ove Knausgaard wrote, that makes it easy to talk about him as if you’ve read him — even if you’ve not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Only Patriotic Choice for President
description: Kamala Harris has demonstrated care, competence and respect for the Constitution — the fundamental qualities necessary for high office.
content: It is hard to imagine a candidate more unworthy to serve as president of the United States than Donald Trump. He has proved himself morally unfit for an office that asks its occupant to put the good of the nation above self-interest. He has proved himself temperamentally unfit for a role that requires the very qualities — wisdom, honesty, empathy, courage, restraint, humility, discipline — that he most lacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Dozens Feared Dead After Migrant Boat Sinks Off Spain
description: At least nine people are known to have died in a sinking off the Canary Islands and 48 more are missing, the latest disaster on the perilous Atlantic crossing from West Africa.
content: Spanish authorities are searching for dozens of migrants who are missing after their boat sank on Saturday off the Canary Islands, killing at least nine people. It is the latest deadly episode along the crossing from West Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Conducted Raids in Lebanon
description: Also, some of the busiest U.S. ports are set to shut down. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Israeli commando units made brief incursions into Lebanon in recent days, as signs emerged that Israel was preparing for a wider invasion targeting Hezbollah. Israel’s defensive minister said today that “the next stage of the war against Hezbollah will soon commence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Conway
title: Britain Is the First Major Economy to Stop Using Coal. It’s a Risky Experiment.
description: Few in Britain will mourn the passing of coal, but it’s hard not to feel a little nervous about what, at its heart, is an experiment, one fraught with danger.
content: Over 100 miles north of London, Britain’s last coal-fired power station, the Ratcliffe-on-Soar plant, will be powered down on Monday, ending Britain’s reliance on coal for power. The plant, outside Nottingham, will cease operations permanently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Patrice: The Movie’ Review: At a Crossroads
description: The emotional core of this crowd-pleasing documentary concerns a couple who cannot marry without jeopardizing their disability benefits.
content: The title of “Patrice: The Movie” is a little misleading. Although this documentary, directed by Ted Passon, certainly offers a biographical portrait of Patrice Jetter, a school crossing guard, disability rights advocate and Special Olympics athlete from New Jersey, its emotional core concerns her relationship with Garry Wickham. Jetter and Wickham want to marry, but doing so — or even living together — could jeopardize their disability benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: The Hammer Museum Chooses a New Director
description: Stepping into Ann Philbin’s shoes will be Zoë Ryan, the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art at the University of Pennsylvania.
content: For nearly 25 years, the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles has been closely identified with its transformative director, Ann Philbin, who last year said that she planned to retire. On Monday the museum announced that it had found a worthy — if little known — successor: Zoë Ryan, the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art at the University of Pennsylvania since 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘The Hills of California,’ Alive With the Sound of Music
description: In Jez Butterworth’s compelling new play, four girls trained to sing close harmony wind up as acrimonious adults.
content: Two sounds greet you at the start of “The Hills of California,” Jez Butterworth’s relentlessly entertaining new play: the crashing of waves on the beaches of Blackpool and the tinkling of a tinny piano being tuned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: An Ohio Businessman Faces Death Threats for Praising His Haitian Workers
description: The lifelong Republican employs fewer Haitians than others in Springfield, but his life has been upended since Donald J. Trump spread falsehoods about immigrants in his hometown.
content: For Jamie McGregor, a businessman in Springfield, Ohio, speaking favorably about the Haitian immigrants he employs has come to this: death threats, a lockdown at his company and posters around town branding him a traitor for hiring immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Monthlong Fire Flares Up Again in Southern California
description: The Line fire, which has burned since Sept. 5, forced another evacuation order this weekend.
content: A wildfire that has been burning in Southern California for nearly a month flared up again over the weekend, forcing another round of evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Britain Shuts Down Last Coal Plant, ‘Turning Its Back on Coal Forever’
description: The Ratcliffe-on-Soar plant was the last surviving coal-burning power station in a country that birthed the Industrial Revolution and fed it with coal.
content: Britain, the nation that launched a global addiction to coal 150 years ago, is shutting down its last coal-burning power station on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In Biden’s Homestretch, Selfies on Air Force One and a Chorus of ‘Thank You, Joe’
description: In the months since President Biden dropped out of the race, Democratic voters have bombarded him with words of gratitude. But they are, at least in part, thanking him for quitting.
content: President Biden was in the mood to break some rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Alissa J. Rubin
title: Facing a Big Test, Iran’s ‘Axis of Resistance’ Flails
description: Iran united militias to take on Israel, but as the Israelis pummel one, Hezbollah, the rest have so far largely failed to come to its aid.
content: The idea was simple: When a big war with Israel broke out, all the members of the Iranian-backed network of militias in the Middle East known as the “axis of resistance” would join the fight in a coordinated push toward their shared goal of destroying the Jewish state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Georgia’s 6-Week Abortion Ban Is Struck Down
description: The ruling is unlikely to be the final word on abortion access in the state, with the expectation that the case will ultimately be decided by the Georgia Supreme Court.
content: A Georgia judge on Monday struck down a state law effectively prohibiting abortions beyond six weeks of pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury and Alison Bruzek
title: The Only Patriotic Choice for President
description: Listen to Kathleen Kingsbury, the Times Opinion Editor, make the case for Kamala Harris.
content: Over the past several months, The New York Times’s editorial board has been making the case over and over again that Donald Trump is unfit to be president. Now, the board turns to the optimistic case for why Kamala Harris is the better choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: seismic
description: This word has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word seismic has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 12 in “Earthquake Rattles Coastal Area Near Los Angeles” by Jill Cowan:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Will the Real Midwest Please Stand Up?
description: The vice-presidential debate, pitting Senator JD Vance of Ohio against Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, shines the spotlight on a complicated region.
content: Follow live updates on the vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine and Greg Mills
title: Your Guide to the Gameplay Forums
description: We’re giving you a tour of this lovely little corner of the internet — and a behind-the-scenes peek at the decisions that help us maintain it.
content: Anyone who plays games is familiar with the sense of satisfaction that comes with solving a tricky puzzle, but getting validation from other solvers can be just as intoxicating. Wouldn’t it be less fun to solve Wordle in two turns if you couldn’t share your score?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Do So Many Women Wear Giant Eyeglasses?
description: A reader wonders why more women start opting for chunky frames at a certain age. Our fashion critic explains the appeal.
content: It’s not a trend, and it’s not actually Mr. Magoo you should be thinking of, but Edna Mode from “The Incredibles.” She’s the fashion reference here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Baker
title: Vintage Shopping Is Booming. Banana Republic and Others Get In on the Action.
description: Last year, apparel resale in the United States grew seven times the rate of the broader retail industry. Independent resellers and corporate giants are getting creative to meet the demand.
content: At her vintage store in Santa Cruz, Calif., Mely Olmeda sells a range of clothing, much of it from the early aughts, including sheer tops, low-rise denim flares and anything with lace or loud prints. She also rents rack space to other vendors, which helps pay the rent and other overhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Senior South Korean Police Officer Sentenced to 3 Years Over Crowd Crush
description: Lee Im-jae, a former district chief, is the most senior official to be convicted in connection with the 2022 disaster that killed nearly 160 Halloween partygoers.
content: A Seoul court sentenced a senior police officer to​ three years in prison on Monday, ​convicting him of contributing through negligence to a Halloween crowd crush that killed nearly 160 people in 2022 in one of South Korea’s worst peacetime disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Trumponomics Could Lead to Trumpflation
description: The former president is contemplating policies that would act like a self-inflicted pandemic.
content: So, will we have a ticker-tape parade to celebrate V-I — victory over inflation — Day? I guess not, but we appear to have pulled it off. The Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of consumer prices rose only 2.2 percent over the past year, within a whisker of the Fed’s 2 percent inflation target. And we got there without the recession that quite a few economists predicted — in fact, the U.S. economy grew 6 percent over the past two years, even as inflation plunged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Embezzlement Trial of Le Pen and the National Rally Party Opens in France
description: The defendants, including 26 other people, are charged with using European Parliament funds for unrelated party expenses.
content: The French far-right leader Marine Le Pen and over 20 other people went on trial in Paris on Monday on charges that they embezzled funds from the European Parliament between 2004 and 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer
title: Israeli Commandos Making Preparatory Raids Into Lebanon, Officials Say
description: Brief incursions in recent days were to prepare the ground for a possible wider ground invasion, the officials said.
content: Israeli commando units have made brief incursions across the border into Lebanon in recent days to prepare the ground for a possible wider invasion in the near future, according to seven Israeli officers and officials and a senior Western official.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stuck in the Middle
description: People caught in limbo, using ingenuity and guile to try to get themselves out.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: After 85 Years, Fixing a Typo The Brontës Would’ve Hated
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 30, 2024.
content: “Three of our greatest writers, and their names are spelled incorrectly. You can’t make it up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Does High School Need to Be Less Demanding?
description: A high school teacher says students “need to do less so that they can do better.” Do you agree?
content: We often hear from students about how their schedules are overloaded — they have too much homework, and they’re running from one extracurricular activity, sport or volunteer project to another. As a result, they don’t sleep enough or spend enough time with their friends and families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: This month’s picks cover Wisconsin moviemaking, New York music-making and Florida moneymaking.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Pentagon Sends Additional Troops to the Middle East
description: The additional forces, which one official placed at between 2,000 and 3,000, will bolster security for the 40,000 U.S. troops already in the region and help defend Israel, officials said.
content: President Biden is sending a “few thousand” more troops to the Middle East, the Pentagon said on Monday, as tensions rise amid Israel’s intensified attacks against Hezbollah militants in Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,200
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for October 1, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Who Shot 2 Outside Los Angeles Synagogues Gets 35 Years in Prison
description: The shootings took place in Pico-Robertson, a neighborhood with a large Jewish population, as the men were leaving services. They survived.
content: A former dental student who shot and wounded two Jewish men as they left synagogues in Los Angeles last year was sentenced on Monday to 35 years in prison, according to federal prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Internet Drug Ring Tricked Buyers With Fake and Deadly Pills, U.S. Says
description: The drugs, which resembled real pharmaceuticals, killed nine people, prosecutors said. They were laced with fentanyl and methamphetamine.
content: The online pharmacies were cheery, helpful-looking spots on the internet, promising the convenience of prescriptions by mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Breaking Up With China Is Hard to Do
description: For many U.S. companies, Chinese partnership may be too important to quit.
content: It’s not an easy time to be an American multinational company that sells to or buys from China. As the governments of the United States and China butt heads, they’re pressuring companies to take sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Richard Fausset
title: In Booming Asheville, Residents Rethink Their Sense of Safety
description: Worries of flooding had not been top of mind as the mountain-ringed city flourished in recent years as a haven for artists, chefs, brewmasters, entrepreneurs and retirees.
content: Erica Scott, a wedding photographer, spent much of her life in California, but moved to Asheville, N.C., 16 years ago with a sense that she was leaving behind the perpetual threat of natural disasters. With its cool mountain climate and a setting hundreds of miles from the ocean, the city seemed like a refuge from some of the worries that come with a warming planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Barrett and Jacey Fortin
title: Hundreds Still Missing in Mountain Towns After ‘History-Making’ Helene
description: President Biden said he would visit the devastated region on Wednesday. The death toll from the hurricane has risen to at least 121 people across six states.
content: National Guard units swarmed over the North Carolina mountains in helicopters, high-water vehicles and a cargo plane on Monday, joining the desperate effort to deliver food, water and emergency supplies to remote mountain communities hit hard by Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: After U.S. Trip, Zelensky Returns to an Enduring War
description: Cities across Ukraine have suffered airstrikes in recent days, and Moscow is pressing a slow advance in the east. Kyiv has hit back against arms depots, trying to disrupt Russian logistics.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky returned to Ukraine this weekend from a high-stakes diplomatic trip to the United States with limited new aid for his armed forces and mounting challenges on the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Hezbollah Is Ready for Possible Israeli Invasion of Lebanon, Deputy Leader Says
description: The televised statement by the deputy leader, Sheikh Naim Qassem, was the first public address by a senior Hezbollah figure since Israel’s killing of the group’s longtime chief, Hassan Nasrallah.
content: Three days after Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed by Israeli bombs near Beirut, the group’s deputy leader said on Monday that it would name a new chief “at the closest opportunity,” without specifying when.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Georgian Revival house in San Francisco, a contemporary home in Los Angeles and a house near the ocean in Long Beach.
content: This house is half a block from Golden Gate Park, a five-minute walk from the park’s rose garden and a 10-minute walk from the California Academy of Sciences. It is also within walking distance of a Russian bakery, several coffee shops and a playground. China Beach, which has a tide pool and sweeping views of the Golden Gate Bridge, is 10 minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Biden Expands Asylum Restrictions at the Southern Border
description: Biden administration officials have credited the policy for leading to the dramatic reduction in illegal crossings.
content: President Biden on Monday expanded the restrictions on asylum that have led to a dramatic drop in illegal crossings into the United States, a move that ensures the crackdown at the southern border will stay in effect for the foreseeable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: The Plan to Save Frank Lloyd Wright’s Only Skyscraper Isn’t Going as Planned
description: Less than two years ago, the building was thought to have been rescued from financial woes. Now the new owners have it on the auction block and some Wright-designed furnishings have already been sold.
content: Frank Lloyd Wright’s only realized skyscraper is just 19 stories, but even 70 years after it was built, Price Tower sits higher than most buildings in Bartlesville, Okla., and the view from the top still stretches to the horizon where the rolling prairie starts to take shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Jonathan Weisman
title: Pennsylvania Republicans Lag Democrats in Early Mail Ballot Requests
description: Encouraging voters to cast mail ballots — and cast them early — benefits political campaigns. But former President Donald J. Trump’s skepticism has hurt Republican efforts in a key state.
content: In the past two election cycles, Republicans have been far less eager to vote by mail than Democrats — and their candidates have suffered because of it. This year, Republicans made Pennsylvania their target for flipping the trend, pledging more than $10 million to persuade G.O.P. voters there to vote by mail in the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Verizon Is Restoring Service After Outages Reported Across the U.S.
description: The number of cases peaked at more than 100,000 Monday morning, according to the website Downdetector. Users complained of being unable to make calls or send texts.
content: Verizon said its engineers were restoring service on Monday evening after thousands of users across the United States reported outages on Monday morning in major cities, including in Atlanta, Chicago, Denver, Los Angeles, New York and Phoenix and across a swath of the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: North Carolina Officials Begin Post-Helene Election Planning
description: While the region hit hardest is largely rural, it holds a healthy share of the state’s nearly 7.7 million registered voters.
content: Four days after historic floods battered western North Carolina, the difficulties facing county officials who are trying to stage a presidential election in the area have begun to take shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Paulina Villegas
title: As Mexico’s President Steps Down, Some Laud His Legacy, but Others Fear It
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador lifted millions out of poverty while eroding democratic norms, allowing his nationalist political movement to expand its sway.
content: To some, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico is a reformer who steered the country toward progress during his six-year presidency. To others, he’s a bulldozer who eroded democratic institutions, and is leaving a host of problems for his successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia to Boost Defense Budget as Ukraine War Drags On
description: The Kremlin plans a 25 percent increase to more than $145 billion in 2025, a year in which it had intended to cut military spending.
content: The Russian government intends to increase its defense expenditures by about a quarter next year, according to a draft state budget released on Monday, signaling the Kremlin’s continued determination to allocate vast resources to the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Why Mount Everest Is Growing Taller Every Year
description: Researchers say that two rivers merged some 89,000 years ago and gave the mightiest peak in the Himalayas a huge growth spurt.
content: Mount Everest is many things. It’s called Chomolungma in Tibetan, and Sagarmatha in Nepali. It’s an iconic part of Earth’s topography, a potentially lethal climbing challenge and a geologic marvel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: The Truth About Tuna
description: How much should you worry about mercury in tuna and other seafood? Experts weigh in.
content: Ahi steak. Akami sashimi. Albacore on sourdough. Whether you smoked yellowfin on the grill or spread skipjack on a sandwich, chances are you’ve had tuna recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Kate Christobek
title: Based on a True Story, or a True Story? In ‘Baby Reindeer’ Lawsuit, Words Matter.
description: A defamation suit against Netflix boils down to how the company presented its story about Martha Scott, a fictionalization of what the show’s creator has described as a real-life stalking incident.
content: The woman who claims to have inspired the character Martha Scott in the Netflix series “Baby Reindeer” can proceed with a defamation lawsuit against the streaming giant, a federal judge in Los Angeles ruled last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Council Passes Rat Birth Control
description: During a momentous week, the business of government went on at the City Council, which approved bills on jaywalking and rats.

content: For two years, stock investors wanting in on the frenzy around artificial intelligence have had only a few tech industry options: big companies like Microsoft and Nvidia. title: Ritzy! Cheddar! Chicken!
description: Everyone’s favorite buttery cracker makes a fantastic coating for chicken breasts.
content: In my 20s, my happy place was the Bed Bath & Beyond near Lincoln Center. (R.I.P.) An eagerness to play house — and to grow up — meant using my meager teaching paychecks to buy a new pot, a new pan or a new knife whenever I felt lost in the world. Nothing calmed my anxious nerves like gliding down those escalators and thumbing my way through the gadgets and housewares that would come to overstock my first adult kitchen.

author: By Elie Levine
title: Frankenstein’s Assistant
description: Creatures lurk in the depths of Kevin Curry and Jeff Chen’s first New York Times collaboration.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is the first collaborative effort in The Times by Kevin Curry and Jeff Chen, and as such, it represents the achievement of a longstanding goal for the two of them. Mr. Chen’s first accepted puzzle, a collaboration with his wife, Jill Denny, came after 22 Times rejections. Now he has 155 New York Times grids to his name, more than half of which are collaborations. He’s also the creator of the daily word game Squeezy. Mr. Curry is a newer constructor with three grids under his belt.

title: His Mother Was Killed by Hamas. Her Death Transformed His Life.
description: The son of a peace activist brutally killed on Oct. 7 is determined to make sure that her dream for Israel does not die with her.
content: The day Vivian Silver’s home burned, her backyard was scattered with her grandchildren’s toys, a blue plastic boat upturned near a rubber duck. Vivian often spent days preparing for their visits, planning trips to the petting zoo and baking birthday cakes molded into the shape of a Barbie or a dinosaur. Her sons, Yonatan and Chen Zeigen, reminded her that she didn’t need to do so much, but Vivian measured her life by the way she made other people feel. The boys teased their mother: As a self-declared no-nonsense feminist, a renowned Israeli peace activist who was used to the sound of mortar fire, how had she stayed so soft?

description: After years as a struggling songwriter, he found his voice with a direct, evocative style that launched his decades-long career as a musician, actor and activist.
content: Kris Kristofferson, who died on Saturday at 88, was most revered for his songwriting, favoring an aphoristic style that surveyed the many detours a life could take. By the time he broke through, at nearly 34 years old, Kristofferson had swerved off prescribed courses a number of times. The son of an Air Force major general and a socially conscious mother, he’d been a Rhodes Scholar, an Army helicopter pilot and a family man before going all in on music in 1965, a decision that splintered his family and left him scuffling for money.

author: By M.H. Miller
title: The Power of Saying No
description: T looks at some of contemporary art’s genuine iconoclasts — celebrated recluses and others who’ve managed to create an alternate way of being a creative person in a world that sometimes scoffs at privacy.
content: There’s a common misconception about the art business that states that, within the industry, there are essentially no rules. True, it’s a vast and murky marketplace with few regulations, but to succeed as an artist within it has often meant, for many, following quite a number of rules. Chief among them is showing up. There are exhibition openings and lunches and galas; there are cocktail hours and auctions and vernissages; there are V.I.P. previews and panels and dinners that last the length of a Frederick Wiseman documentary.
